perturbation.original_text: Distributor shall pay Company within thirty (30) days of Distributor's or, as the case may be, the end-user's receipt of Products.
perturbation.changed_text: Distributor shall pay Company within sixty (60) days of Distributor's or, as the case may be, the end-user's receipt of Products.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the payment terms from 30 days to 60 days may violate the Illinois Sales Representative Act, which mandates timely payments to sales representatives. Although the contract does not explicitly state that the Distributor is a 'sales representative,' extending the payment period increases the risk of non-compliance.
perturbation.law_explanation: The Illinois Sales Representative Act (820 ILCS 120/2) mandates that principals must pay sales representatives all commissions due at the time of termination of the contract or agreement. If the distributor is considered a sales representative under this law, then this may be a violation of it.

perturbation.original_text: During the Term of this Agreement and for a period of twelve (12) months thereafter, the Distributor (on behalf of itself, each of its affiliates and each of their respective representatives) agrees that it will not directly or indirectly solicit or hire any executive, managerial or technical employee of the Company or any of its affiliates.
perturbation.changed_text: During the Term of this Agreement and for a period of twenty-four (24) months thereafter, the Distributor (on behalf of itself, each of its affiliates and each of their respective representatives) agrees that it will not directly or indirectly solicit or hire any executive, managerial or technical employee of the Company or any of its affiliates.
perturbation.explanation: Extending the non-solicitation period to 24 months may be deemed an unreasonable restraint of trade under Illinois law, particularly if it unduly restricts the employee's ability to find employment.
perturbation.law_explanation: The Illinois Antitrust Act prohibits contracts that unreasonably restrain trade. A two-year non-solicitation clause, depending on the scope and the employee's position, could be seen as an unreasonable restraint if it prevents employees from seeking employment opportunities.

perturbation.original_text: Company will make reasonable efforts to procure a policy, which is non-cancelable, except upon thirty (30) days, advance notice to the Distributor.
perturbation.changed_text: Company will make reasonable efforts to procure a policy, which is non-cancelable, except upon ten (10) days, advance notice to the Distributor.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notice period for insurance cancellation to 10 days may violate general principles of good faith and fair dealing implied in Illinois contracts, especially if it leaves the Distributor with insufficient time to secure alternative coverage.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing
perturbation.law_explanation: While not a codified statute, Illinois law recognizes an implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing in every contract. Reducing the insurance cancellation notice period to 10 days might be viewed as a breach of this covenant if it prejudices the Distributor's ability to protect its interests, particularly given the Distributor is named as an additional insured under the policy.
